result.markdown:
--- filters: - lightbox lightbox: auto --- ::: callout-note - Le document qui suit n'est qu'un programme fait il y a 3-4 ans. Utilisant très peu Python, je n'ai pas documenté les fonctions, plus ou moins obsures, qui ont été utilisées. - L'exécution a été réalisé le noyau `python3` de jupyter. - Le document n'a pas été compilé en PDF, seule cette version html est disponible. ::: # **Python** Deux paquets d'analyse: principalement `lifelines` (km, cox, aft...) et `statsmodels``` (estimation logit en temps discret, kaplan-Meier, Cox). Le package ```statsmodels``` est également ne mesure d'estimer des courbes de séjour de type Kaplan-Meier et des modèles à risque proportionnel de Cox. Le package ```lifelines``` couvre la quasi totalité des méthodes standards, à l'exception des les risques concurrents. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd import patsy as pt import lifelines as lf import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import statsmodels as sm ``` ::: Chargement de la base ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} trans = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mthevenin/analyse_duree/master/bases/transplantation.csv") trans.head(10) trans.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 103 entries, 0 to 102 Data columns (total 10 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 id 103 non-null int64 1 year 103 non-null int64 2 age 103 non-null int64 3 died 103 non-null int64 4 stime 103 non-null int64 5 surgery 103 non-null int64 6 transplant 103 non-null int64 7 wait 103 non-null int64 8 mois 103 non-null int64 9 compet 103 non-null int64 dtypes: int64(10) memory usage: 8.2 KB ``` ::: ::: ## Package lifelines **Documentation**: ### Non Paramétrique: Kaplan Meier **Estimateur KM et durée médiane** ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} T = trans['stime'] E = trans['died'] from lifelines import KaplanMeierFitter kmf = KaplanMeierFitter() kmf.fit(T,E) print(kmf.survival_function_) a = "DUREE MEDIANE:" b = kmf.median_survival_time_ print(a,b) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` KM_estimate timeline 0.0 1.000000 1.0 0.990291 2.0 0.961165 3.0 0.932039 5.0 0.912621 ... ... 1400.0 0.151912 1407.0 0.151912 1571.0 0.151912 1586.0 0.151912 1799.0 0.151912 [89 rows x 1 columns] DUREE MEDIANE: 100.0 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} kmf.plot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](17-Python_files/figure-html/cell-5-output-2.png){} ::: ::: **Comparaison des fonctions de survie** ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} ax = plt.subplot(111) kmf = KaplanMeierFitter() for name, grouped_df in trans.groupby('surgery'): kmf.fit(grouped_df['stime'], grouped_df['died'], label=name) kmf.plot(ax=ax) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](17-Python_files/figure-html/cell-6-output-1.png){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} from lifelines.statistics import multivariate_logrank_test results = multivariate_logrank_test(trans['stime'], trans['surgery'], trans['died']) results.print_summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
t_0 -1
null_distribution chi squared
degrees_of_freedom 1
test_name multivariate_logrank_test
test_statistic p -log2(p)
0 6.59 0.01 6.61
``` ::: ::: ## Semi paramétrique: Cox ### Estimation ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} model = 'year + age + C(surgery) -1' X = pt.dmatrix(model, trans, return_type='dataframe') design_info = X.design_info YX = X.join(trans[['stime','died']]) YX.drop(['C(surgery)[0]'], axis=1, inplace=True) YX.head() from lifelines import CoxPHFitter cph = CoxPHFitter() cph.fit(YX, duration_col='stime', event_col='died') cph.print_summary() cph.plot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
model lifelines.CoxPHFitter
duration col 'stime'
event col 'died'
baseline estimation breslow

C(surgery)[1] -0.99 0.37 0.44 -1.84 -0.13 0.16 0.88 0.00 -2.26 0.02 5.40
year -0.12 0.89 0.07 -0.25 0.01 0.78 1.01 0.00 -1.78 0.08 3.72
age 0.03 1.03 0.01 0.00 0.06 1.00 1.06 0.00 2.19 0.03 5.12

Concordance 0.65
Partial AIC 584.61
log-likelihood ratio test 17.63 on 3 df
-log2(p) of ll-ratio test 10.90
``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](17-Python_files/figure-html/cell-8-output-3.png){} ::: ::: ### Tests hypothèse PH **Test PH: Schoenfeld Méthode 1** ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} cph.check_assumptions(YX,p_value_threshold=0.05) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` The ``p_value_threshold`` is set at 0.05. Even under the null hypothesis of no violations, some covariates will be below the threshold by chance. This is compounded when there are many covariates. Similarly, when there are lots of observations, even minor deviances from the proportional hazard assumption will be flagged. With that in mind, it's best to use a combination of statistical tests and visual tests to determine the most serious violations. Produce visual plots using ``check_assumptions(..., show_plots=True)`` and looking for non-constant lines. See link [A] below for a full example. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
null_distribution chi squared
degrees_of_freedom 1
model <lifelines.CoxPHFitter: fitted with 103 total ...
test_name proportional_hazard_test
test_statistic p -log2(p)
C(surgery)[1] km 4.01 0.05 4.47
rank 3.74 0.05 4.23
age km 1.18 0.28 1.86
rank 1.06 0.30 1.72
year km 2.07 0.15 2.73
rank 2.08 0.15 2.75
``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1. Variable 'C(surgery)[1]' failed the non-proportional test: p-value is 0.0452. Advice: with so few unique values (only 2), you can include `strata=['C(surgery)[1]', ...]` in the call in `.fit`. See documentation in link [E] below. --- [A] https://lifelines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jupyter_notebooks/Proportional%20hazard%20assumption.html [B] https://lifelines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jupyter_notebooks/Proportional%20hazard%20assumption.html#Bin-variable-and-stratify-on-it [C] https://lifelines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jupyter_notebooks/Proportional%20hazard%20assumption.html#Introduce-time-varying-covariates [D] https://lifelines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jupyter_notebooks/Proportional%20hazard%20assumption.html#Modify-the-functional-form [E] https://lifelines.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jupyter_notebooks/Proportional%20hazard%20assumption.html#Stratification ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` [] ``` ::: ::: **Test PH: Schoenfeld Méthode 2** ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} from lifelines.statistics import proportional_hazard_test zph = proportional_hazard_test(cph, YX, time_transform='all') zph.print_summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
null_distribution chi squared
degrees_of_freedom 1
model <lifelines.CoxPHFitter: fitted with 103 total ...
test_name proportional_hazard_test
test_statistic p -log2(p)
C(surgery)[1] identity 5.54 0.02 5.75
km 4.01 0.05 4.47
log 3.69 0.05 4.19
rank 3.74 0.05 4.23
age identity 1.61 0.20 2.29
km 1.18 0.28 1.86
log 0.61 0.44 1.20
rank 1.06 0.30 1.72
year identity 0.80 0.37 1.43
km 2.07 0.15 2.73
log 1.34 0.25 2.02
rank 2.08 0.15 2.75
``` ::: ::: **Test PH: intéraction** ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} from lifelines.utils import to_episodic_format from lifelines import CoxTimeVaryingFitter ``` ::: *Transformation de la base YX* ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} long = to_episodic_format(YX, duration_col='stime', event_col='died') ``` ::: *Création de la variable d'intéraction* ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} long['surgery_t'] = long['C(surgery)[1]'] * long['stop'] ``` ::: *Estimation* ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} ctv = CoxTimeVaryingFitter() ctv.fit(long, id_col='id', event_col='died', start_col='start', stop_col='stop',) ctv.print_summary(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ### Variable dynamique binaire ## Modèle à temps discret ### Ajustement continu Modèle logistique estimé avec le paquet ```statsmodel```. La fonction ```to_episodic_format``` de ```lifelines``` permet de mettre en forme la base. Pour la durée, on utilisera ici la variable **mois** (regroupement de stime par intervalle de 30 jours). ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} import statsmodels.formula.api as smf #type R formule => ce qu'on utilisera# import statsmodels.api as sm #type python# ``` ::: **Transformation de la base en format long** ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} td = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mthevenin/analyse_duree/master/bases/transplantation.csv") td.drop(['id'], axis=1, inplace=True) td['dur'] = td['mois'] td = to_episodic_format(td, duration_col='mois', event_col='died') ``` ::: **Evaluation de l'ajustement avec des fonctions quadratiques** ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} td['t2'] = td['stop']**2 td['t3'] = td['stop']**3 fit1 = smf.glm(formula= "died ~ stop", data=td, family=sm.families.Binomial()).fit() fit2 = smf.glm(formula= "died ~ stop + t2", data=td, family=sm.families.Binomial()).fit() fit3 = smf.glm(formula= "died ~ stop + t2 + t3", data=td, family=sm.families.Binomial()).fit() ``` ::: **Comparaison des AIC** ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} print("AIC pour ajustement t1") print(fit1.aic) print("AIC pour ajustement durée t1 + t2") print(fit2.aic) print("AIC pour ajustement durée t1 + t2 + t3") print(fit3.aic) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` AIC pour ajustement t1 504.5211512753311 AIC pour ajustement durée t1 + t2 492.11522432726747 AIC pour ajustement durée t1 + t2 + t3 486.50534103180416 ``` ::: ::: **Estimation du modèle** ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} tdfit = smf.glm(formula= "died ~ stop + t2 + t3 + year + age + surgery", data=td, family=sm.families.Binomial()).fit() tdfit.summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ```{=html}
Generalized Linear Model Regression Results

``` ::: ::: ### Ajustement discret *Création des intervalles pour l'exemple (quantile de la durée en mois)* ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} td['ct4'] = pd.qcut(td['stop'],[0, .25, .5, .75, 1.]) td['ct4'].value_counts(normalize=True)*100 td.ct4 = pd.Categorical(td.ct4) td['ct4'] = td.ct4.cat.codes ``` ::: Pour chaque individu, on conserve une seule observation par intervalle. ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} td2 = td td2['t'] = td2['ct4'] td2 = td2.sort_values(['id', 'stop']) td2 = td2.groupby(['id','ct4']).last() ``` ::: **Estimation** ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} td2fit = smf.glm(formula= "died ~ C(t) + year + age + surgery", data=td2, family=sm.families.Binomial()).fit() td2fit.summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Modèle paramétrique de type AFT ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} from lifelines import WeibullAFTFitter, LogLogisticAFTFitter ``` ::: **Weibull** ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} aftw = WeibullAFTFitter() aftw.fit(YX, duration_col='stime', event_col='died') aftw.print_summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Package statsmodels https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/duration.html Le package permet d'estimer des fonction de séjour de type Kaplan-Meier et des modèles de Cox. ## Kaplan-Meier ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} km = sm.SurvfuncRight(trans["stime"], trans["died"]) km.summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=25} ```{=html}
Surv prob Surv prob SE num at risk num events

``` ::: ::: Les test du log-rank sont disponibles avec la fonction ```survdiff``` (nom idem R). Au niveau graphique, la programmation semble un peu lourde et mériterait d'être simplifiée (donc non traitée). **Comparaison de S(t) à partir des tests du log-rank**
Résultat: (statistique de test, p-value) *Test non pondéré* ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} sm.duration.survdiff(trans.stime, trans.died, trans.surgery) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=26} ``` (6.5900123232343875, 0.010255246157888975) ``` ::: ::: *Breslow* ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} sm.duration.survdiff(trans.stime, trans.died, trans.surgery, weight_type='gb') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=27} ``` (8.989753779902493, 0.0027149757927903417) ``` ::: ::: *Tarone-Ware* ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} sm.duration.survdiff(trans.stime, trans.died, trans.surgery, weight_type='tw') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=28} ``` (8.462352726451392, 0.0036257256194570653) ``` ::: ::: ## Modèle de Cox ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} mod = smf.phreg("stime ~ year + age + surgery ",trans, status='died', ties="efron") rslt = mod.fit() print(rslt.summary()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Results: PHReg ============================================================= Model: PH Reg Sample size: 103 Dependent variable: stime Num. events: 75 Ties: Efron ------------------------------------------------------------- log HR log HR SE HR t P>|t| [0.025 0.975] ------------------------------------------------------------- year -0.1196 0.0673 0.8872 -1.7765 0.0757 0.7775 1.0124 age 0.0296 0.0135 1.0300 2.1872 0.0287 1.0031 1.0577 surgery -0.9873 0.4363 0.3726 -2.2632 0.0236 0.1584 0.8761 ============================================================= Confidence intervals are for the hazard ratios ``` ::: :::
